comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Pianist and organist, based in New York City. I can't find a biographical sketch of her. She is on the New York Times' Zombie List of musicians, with a request for biographical information. She was mentioned in The Times for recitals and other professional appearances up until 1950. theater.nytimes.com/library/cyber/mirapaul/0509mirapaul-z... There is some information at americanjewisharchives.org: "Freid, Sara Sokolsky (Mrs Alexander Freid); b. Korytki, Poland. To US 1916.· Royal Academy of Music, Sorbonne. • Pianist, organist, tchr, NYC; author in field. • See: WWIAJ [Who's Who In American Jewry], 1928, 1938." See also:

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: It is not even clear wether her name was "Sokolsky-Fried" (which is likelier IMO) or "Sokolsky-Freid" resp. "Sokolsky Fried" / "Sokolksy Freid". There are citations of all versions of the name in books, newspapers etc., but I couldn't find a detailed report either.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Newspapers sometimes spelled it Fried, but the biographical sources seem to be consistent withe Freid for both Sara and her husband Alexander (a musical conductor). This looks like another one where the subject was invited to Bain's office for a portrait:

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: From the American Jewish Chronicle of Feb 9, 1917, p 442. books.google.com/books?id=1UE6AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA442 "Sara Sokolsky Freid will give her first and organ recital of this season on evening February 12 at the Aeolian Hall. The young organist has recently returned from Germany where she was for a short time held interned as a prisoner of war, her husband being a French citizen. While abroad, she studied with the greatest pianists of Europe and is now a musician of the highest rank. Sara Sokolsky Freid is one of the few women organists in the country. Her performances on this instrument have won praise from the highest authorities. The recital on Monday evening promises to be a real musical treat which will live long in the memory of those who will hear it."

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/artolog] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] You may be right. At least I found out who was this fellow ;)
